content.value: What you need:
Sorters (Anything you ALREADY own no need to purchase anything. The only requirement is that the items come in different colors and have multiples)
How I approached the activity:
Theo was using all blue bristle blocks while playing so I seized the moment and “sorted” with him.
I began building with the pink bristle blocks and asked if Theo could hand me another pink block (he handed me a few blocks, one included a pink one.)
I took out green and started putting them into a pile. Theo noticed and had been watching and ended up handing me another green one to add to my pile.
Whether he recognized and identified that it was green or handed it to me by coincidence he became involved (and that’s what I wanted!!!)
What you need:
Any item that you child enjoys using or playing with
How I approach This:
This activity is an "everyday/anyday" activity. Although the child might not understand entirely what "taking turns" means we are always verbalizing our interactions when we are together

When we notice he wants to get involved with what we are doing or using we verbalize it. "It looks like you would like a turn too. First its mommas turn then its Theo's turn." Then as soon as we see him calmly waiting, we follow up with "Ok I'm all done its Theo's turn now" and then hand him the object.

As we continue doing this, I notice he willingly "shares" and knows that we follow through with what we say. This makes him more willing to wait. It is important that if you say something you follow through with it.

It's best to do this when you notice they are performing the behavior you desire because then every time you say these words to them they know what you expect and what they need to do to get a turn in return.
Your child might not fully understand what we are showing them and implementing but we are setting the standards/expectations. This sets up a successful time later when interacting with others.

This does not have to be done as a sit down activity. Incorporate this into daily life. We do this a ton when Jesse plays the guitar because he is os interested in touching the guitar. You can practice this skill anytime!
What you will need:
A simple recipe
Ingredients
Mixer for you and your little
Possibly an oven
How I approached this:
For baking activities, I like to pick the simple recipes that have few ingredients and steps. Theo is so little right now (1.5 years); his attention span is so short.
Typically I get the bake boxes from the grocery store where you just need to ad milk, egg butter, etc.
If your child is older you could go with something more complex depending on their interest/abilities. There are endless ways to make baking easy or more difficult.

Baking activities are perfect for young children. It is particularly beneficial when they can become hands on touching or mixing with hands. I have a child size spatula or two for Theo to use when we bake.
If he is not mixing Theo really likes to pour the dry mixes in. Sometimes we count eggs and measure together also.
Using hands to mix is such a wonderful sensory experience. They learn not only from their hands on a strict sensory level but on a scientific level when dry and wet ingredients are added together.
Let your child lead you through this one. They will tell you what they are up to getting in on and what they are uncomfortable doing.
Talk about your steps. Let them take on appropriate steps. Remember items can get dangerously hot when baking.
What you will need:
Family photo album or single family photos. You could even use your smart phone gallery
How I approached this:
One of Theo's favorite things is family so what better way to get those cognitive wheels spinning other than pulling out some recent (and older) family photos?
Recognition and being able to tell the difference between objects is a wonderful beginning to the active cognitive learning journey.

Later comes counting, patterning and more advanced sorting (shape, color, size, etc). If recognition of familiar people or things is too easy you can introduce color/object sorting of simple attributes.

You could also introduce rote counting (counting verbally straight through "1,2,3,4,5". If that is too easy you can introduce counting with one to one correspondence: pointing to each object as you count it.
Still too easy? Throw in that "ABABAB" patterning (ex: red, blue, red, blue). Since Theo is only 1.5 it was age appropriate that I stayed at family recognition both new and older photos.
It's not so easy for a 1 year old mind to recall most people, places and things!
What you will need:

A pack of thick crayons any shape (I like the Mellissa and Doug set. 5 dollars on 
amazon and have lasted Theo very long)
How I approached this:

Although the crayons are thick, they are training those little wrists, hands and finger muscles for greatness. Open ended coloring is something I love for young children: it’s child lead, therapeutic, they make whatever they desire (could also relate to emotional development).
Little do they know they are actually doing some great things for those little hand muscles (and brains)!

Theo is a fan- sometimes I will switch them out for markers and sometimes even chalk! Providing the child with a variety of materials will keep them longer and give those muscles a bunch of different sizes and shapes to learn to work with.
You can switch up the things they are coloring too-there’s more than paper to use as a muse-boxes, canvas’, poster boards, etc-be creative and open!

The older the children get, it becomes a great opportunity to teach grip on writing utensils (don’t expect this to be anywhere near correct at first!!-the first step is to train the muscles and make them strong to hold their utensils in the future.) You may even have to model how to use a crayon/marker etc. at first!
What you will need:
Your child
Another child
My thoughts on playdates:
It is so difficult to get children and people in general together during this pandemic. Make sure to do it safely, but don’t forget to get your (healthy) kiddos together still!

Children need social interaction more than anything. 
These days children have become so focused on technology that we have almost forgotten the importance of face-to-face interaction.
Children need us (the world needs us) to prepare them with the appropriate tools to function with one another!

Every interaction and time they get together with a friend (even if it is the same one) is going to be different-so it is good for your little one to see and experience and react to these different situations.
Could even categorize as social/emotional, cognitive & motor development (children learn SO much through play!)
What you need:
Playdough, anykind
Any easily washable toys
How I approached this:

What child doesn’t like putting things where they don’t belong? Play dough is such a great way for a child to explore and improve sensory and motor skills, but when you add to it, it makes it that much more beneficial.

The ways in which the children can now use and benefit just double (yup, just by adding to playdough). When I do this kind of activity with Theo, he, (a one-year-old), will sit there for a while- 10, 20, 30 minutes.
For a one-year-old that is a HUGE amount of time to be working on something. He can now play with just the dough, he can play with just the additive OR he can use both together.

Every parent can benefit from 30, even 20 minutes of “space.” THIS is your activity (Playing WITH them is ideal-but I hear parents say a lot they “need a break”-so here it is).
Switching out items (if the child loses interest or time spent has decreased is a great idea if needed). You can literally add anything!
If the child is a little older, making the play dough with them provides your child with an even more rich learning experience!
What you need:
A place
Some Friends
Your kid!
How I see Play Dates:
I love play dates. Children learn so much through play and interaction-a little bit of everything to be exact.
They learn to socialize, learn about cause and effect, learn problem solving skills (on a whole new level-with others), learn about theirs and other’s emotions and SO much more.

The question is, “What DON’T children learn from play?” I like to switch up who Theo plays with and where and children who he is familiar with as well as children we don’t know well, (why we visit the park!).

This allows him to see different children in different situations. It’s good to expose them to things like this because the more they see, the more they learn to “handle.” If they need help, you are there to do so.

It’s so hard to get out during this pandemic-so even if they are around children who are family, or they know well, it’s still beneficial because when it comes down to it, every situation/ play date is different!
Side note:
I like to expose Theo to all ages also. He plays a lot with two girls; one is 9 months younger than him and the other is a year and a half older than him.

It’s so cool to see the difference in play and interaction-(yes- they were ALL interacting-whether it was through words or actions!). Children can learn from older children and be superior and helpful to younger.
What you will need:
A Location
Your Child
How I approached this:
Today we braved the good ‘ol northeast cold and wandered outside. Theo climbed up our backyard hill (pretty steep), pushed himself in his cozy coup (car), and crawled in between our bushes.

Although we were supposed to go to the park, it was closed off due to weather conditions and I felt better keeping him close to home-more outside time and we could come right in if he became very cold.
With covid still going on, we also felt better to stay home today, knowing there would be no one else there for Theo to play with.
Whatever the situation, make the best of it. Outdoor play is just as fun for the child, no matter the location!!
Side note:

Don’t have much of a yard/space? Home-make an obstacle course! (literally you can use anything!! ; Rulers to jump over, cones to run around, spaces to sprint, etc. You can use whatever you have-be creative-your little one will love it
What you will need:
Any sort of colored connectors (legos, monkeys, etc) I used trains because we have them
How I approached this:
This can be done with any sort of colorful connectors-use what you have-don’t need to spend a bunch. I chose the trains because we had them handy and he happened to be interested in them at the time.

I simply showed Theo how to connect the trains and then left them alone. As we played together, I continued to connect them every so often and as I did, Theo also wanted to too, (know it won’t be easy to get children involved at time- YOU have to become excited and interested to get them interested!)

On Theo’s train there are little holes and hooks that connect one another to each other. For a little one this can be challenging. This takes a lot of problem-solving skills and coordination to make it work.
Theo wasn’t able to achieve it the first few tries, but as he kept going it began working out for him (inconsistently). I kept him motivated, (cheered for him), excited and he continued to try!
What you will need:
Parent
Child
How I approached this:

So, this “activity” I kind of let roll. I went in knowing I’d be working with him most of the gymnastics class- with physical activities, but I also let him “choose” which direction we went with this. If he approached a child, I backed off.

I knew Theo had a “need” to interact with other children and he was so interested in them. Even though I planned this to be a more direct instead of indirect activity, I quickly realized it wasn’t what HE NEEDED.
I was able to identify he simply needed both, (children interaction with my support).

He would occasionally turn and look to make sure I was there and for almost what seemed like the look of “approval.” Lesson plans are great ways to outline meaningful lessons for children, but they are GUIDELINES, nothing that has to be set in stone.
What’s best for your child is not planned-they are ideas and may change depending on what is best for them in that moment!
Don’t be afraid to make some changes even if in the moment! Our best interest is the child!
What you will need:
Paint
Paint brushes or sponges
Platform for painting (canvas, paper, box, egg cartons)
How I approached this:

Before this, Theo had only painted once when he was about 10 months old. Today he had a blast. It was all new for him! Knowing his age and abilities, I only introduced 3 colors-primaries-red, blue and yellow.

I did introduce many different sponges and brushes to paint with. Before we even started painting, I let Theo play with and explore the sponges and brushes. Then one color at a time, I poured them out (into an egg carton-makes great small cups for paint!) This gave me an opportunity to properly introduce the colors. Once I did this for each, I let him go at it!

He was a natural and very into it. Even though it was a small painting surface, Theo spent time covering and layering every last bit of it. This soon became a finger-painting activity, (Theo’s choice).
A lot of parents are “against” painting or “messy” activities in the house, but there are ways to get around this:
Choose washable paint (I always do)
Prepare the working space-lay down newspapers-blankets, etc. if you are worried about a mess.
Set expectations- if your child is a bit older you can let them know you expect the paint to stay in the designated area that you have set up. G

GUYS, you can even throw your little one in the bathtub to paint and then after, just turn the water on and it all washes away. Seriously though, it’s so easy and this way your child is still getting to their messy (but enriching) activity that they really benefit from.
They learn colors, get in some sensory play (more than likely), and get to express themselves-because a lot of times it’s hard to!

en-US.description: Here is a fun painting activity for children ages 1 to 4

content.value: What you will need:
Any size Ziplock bag
Jelly like filling (whatever you have. I used left over jell-o from an activity the day before but you can use hair gel, clear vasolines, etc)
Items to put in to squish around (glitter, gems, thick stickers)
How I approached this:
For this, I left it open-ended ( are you noticing a theme with me). I gave Theo a few choices as to what he wanted to add to the bag and then did the filling with what I had available.

For the “squishy” part I used left over jell-o from the sensory activity the day before (knew my lesson and I had it available-got my use out of it ). I offered three things to put inside and of course he chose to add every single last bit of each to the bag.

It seemed the best part for him was filling the bag- and that’s OK! He spent little time squishing them around once in the bag. (not every lesson will be successful as you see it to be-totally normal).
Children will “tell” us what they need. Theo didn’t need and benefit as much from that stimulation or maybe he had enough by the time we got to this activity.
It happens!!
What you will need:
You
Your kid
How I approached this:
So, for this one, I did “Eye Spy” while we were coloring on Theo’s easel. Right now, Theo can solidly identify the color purple off the top of his head.

However, knowing this, I took this “activity” as a learning opportunity for him. 
I KNEW he didn’t know most all colors yet and some others weren’t so consistently recalled. But he was very interested in his crayons and coloring on his easel. Because he was so interested and concentrated on this, I knew he would be taking it all in and more apt to respond.
Did he know more or all of his colors after this? NO, and it’s not expected. This would be something great to do a few times (since children learn through interest and repetition).
For our little ones to fully understand (or even partially), and to comprehend and recall what he remembers off the top of his head, it would NEED to be done multiple times.
Take all opportunities given by the children to “get in there” and start teaching! (This can be done anywhere or with any color type objects).
What will you need:
Music
Any kind of scarves or long pieces of cloth
How I approached this:
Dancing, alone, is so great for children to let loose-so this time I decided to add a little “spunk.” As I held a scarf and danced around, Theo took one and “wore” it on his head.

He would take and switch out colors that he’d continue to put on his head. Once he put one on his head, he’d spin and dance until it fell off and the proceeded to do it again! Theo thrives off of self-expression activities like these.
He lets loose and becomes silly with so much laughter (a wonderful thing for a parent to see and experience!).
He also tried to involve our three dogs. He would sit with each of them and “offer” a scarf by placing it on each of their heads and got a kick out of it.
(the dogs didn’t mind either )
What you will need:
Water/sink
Soap
How I approached this:

This is another one of my long-term activities. A young child isn’t going to be able to recall steps to hand washing or most self-care tasks within the first try. Luckily Theo is at a place in his childhood where he copies EVERYTHING we do.
So, when it comes to hand washing and how I approach it is simple (for me) and effective- I talk through what I am doing (all the time).
Example: “First I’ll turn the sink on, then wet my hands.”
“Next I’m going to add some soap.”, etc. With these descriptions, I do actions to show what I am saying.
As I slowly go through my steps, verbally and physically, Theo tries his best to do the same, (skipping maybe some steps and movements).

Without me modeling it each time, Theo may be able to recall some of these movements or steps, but I would not expect him to be doing all/everything any time soon, especially if I’m not doing this all the time with him.
Our young children need us-they love when we become consumed and involved with them too!
We also like to sing when we wash.
Here’s the song we sing (and do movements too as we sing them):

Tops and bottoms,
Tops and bottoms.
In-between
In-between
All around my hands,
All around my hands,
Make them clean,
Make them clean!
This may help a child who doesn’t want to actually be washing their hands and may take their mind off of what they are doing and make it much more fun!
What you will need:
Yourself
Your Child
Music - Optional
How I approached this:
What a great way to have your little one express themselves and destress from life and those little (or big) feelings and stressors.
Practicing deep breathes while doing this is great for little ones who simply just need time to breathe.
Music is good for children to be silly or let loose while doing this or even calming music, (depending on what the child needs that day).
This is also great for young children who may be stuck inside or at least inside most of the day-to get some blood flowing and positive vibes to get through the day!
What you will need:
Box, bin or basket
Sensory bottle (I make mine with materials I purchase at the dollar store)
Stress balls
No mess coloring book (Melissa and Doug is our favorite)
Feelings book
Clappers
Slinky
How I approached this:

I used this time to introduce Theodore to tools in which will help him with his emotions. “Calm Down” boxes can include anything! I prefer a sensory bottle (or two), some kind of ball to squeeze, a “silly toy” (I have clappers), a quiet toy or activity and a slinky (something new).
All of these things only come out when he is feeling upset. This makes them “special” and different enough that it catches his attention each time.
I introduced these (once) before he actually started using this box so when I took it would he would know what each item was for and how to use it.

I noticed Theo makes the squeezing motion when he is upset (stress ball) and likes to watch things (sensory bottle). He does well with a silly distraction (clappers) and likes to do art (no mess coloring book-the best in case he is still upset and throws it---makes NO mess; it’s just water).
This is one of those moments that is benefitted from observing your child (you’ll know how to help them best in these circumstances.)
If you know how they react to certain situations and what they like and what the react best to, putting this box together will be a breeze!
This is great in helping your little one with their feelings and will help you when they are feeling certain ways.
What you will need:
Kinetic Sand
Dinosaurs (or another interesting toy, cars, trains, dolls)

Okay, I will be honest. Theo did not love this as much as I was expecting. 
It happens! But I did take a moment and think about his interests and added some of his favorite dinosaurs and when I did.
BOOM, it was a win.
He was hooked. Adding and removing can be done as much as needed. Interests can change quickly sometimes.

Some children might be fine with just the sand. 
Play around and see what works best for you kiddo! If you see them lose interest that is your time to switch out or help get them involved (play with them, show them what they can do with it).
This is great for children to explore different ways of using objects to meet their developmental needs way past the sensory.
What you will need:
Mirror (preferably a safe one a child can access when they'd like)
Your child
You
How I Approached This

We recently had gotten Theo his own mirror (from amazon) so he can begin to see himself, what he looks like and maybe at times what he feels like, (we sometimes forget, but children often DON'T know what they look like unless they are able to see themselves quite a bit daily).
This activity involved a lot of prompting on my end, but this is ok especially when they are being "introduced" to new things.

As soon as Theo stepped in front of it he instantly began smiling/laughing. 
So I responded with, "How are you feeling? Are you happy? silly? etc.
Because Theo is still so young, I am aware that he doesn't have many words to use to describe how he's feeling or what he is feeling even looks like.
Sometimes in all our frustration and unawareness we forget that these young children are looking for help when they have BIG feelings going on in their little bodies.
So this is a wonderful "activity" to give them those words and begin to introduce those words that will one day help them to better express themselves.
I would also recommend doing this often, daily if possible. You will notice your little ones (if possible) will return to the mirrors and watch themselves quite a bit 😁
What you will need:
Bin or Basket
Assorted Snacks
Paint for sign
Paper, cardstock or canvas for sign
How I approached this:
Our family lives in New England, so we get a good amount of snowstorms and have had bad weather often during this winter season.

Staying focused on friendship and community, we decided to show a little extra appreciation for our delivery people. Theo painted a small canvas and helped me pick out some snacks to add into a bin for our mail and delivery workers.

Once we wrote our “thank you” to them and placed it in the bin, Theo helped pack it with yummy things to eat! As we loaded the basket, we talked about our delivery workers and how they work for a long time some days and could be hungry and thirsty and not get much time to feed their bellies.

We talked about how much they help us get things we need when we are uncomfortable going out in the weather, and deliver it right to our door. I explained they take care of us so we will now take care of them!
Their hard work and bravery keeps us safe and it is the least we can do to give back.
What you will need:
Nothing! Just show up!
How I approached this:
I signed Theo up for a 5 week, once a week gymnastics class. He’s done it before, but when he was much younger. Most gyms offer a free class (look into ones near you!) and he loved it.

It’s a great alternative to not being able to be as active as you’d like because of cold weather. I love his gym because they always switch it up. Even though it’s really the same structures, they move them around the gym and combine different ones together and the kids love it.

Theo loves to climb and constantly walks up and rides down the slides. I love seeing him try and interact with others the more we go. Today I stepped back as I watched Theo run and “join” the other children (mixed ages, up to 5).

He hasn't said anything yet but it is wonderful to see him become more comfortable around other children, enough to walk away from me a bit. Most children his age don’t say much, if anything, they tend to look at one another and make movements to figure each other out!
Getting children out, whether it be a class, sport, zoo, museum, etc will help aid those social skills especially if you're home-teaching and they have little exposure to others.
What you will need:
A place, a buddy and a kid
How I approached this:

Today we went over to one of our close friends’ house, (practically family). We see them once a week. They have two girls, one is 3 and the other 1. She had another visitor over as well, he was about 4 months older than Theo.

I was really excited because I love to expand Theo’s play group/friends and it's interesting to see new dynamics. It’s also good practice for him to learn and be around new personalities because all children are different.

Developmentally they are all so different but they played so well together. Theo waited turns and had quick responses to me and children, especially when waiting to take turns, being patient and being careful of other children’s bodies.
The more Theo plays with others, the more I see such wonderful growth and progress with him.
What you will need:
Your kid
Coffee Filters
How I approached this:
This one only requires two coffee filters (and maybe a few for back up)! You place one under each foot and “skate” away!

This gets those big muscles moving and requires some coordination to keep those filters on the floor and under their feet. Theo really liked this because we could get super silly with it. Although this activity started with a bang and lots of laughter, it was short lived (which was expected).
Activities lasting 5-10 minutes in toddler years are excellent-their attention spans are super short! I did leave out the filters and Theo revisited this one a few times throughout the morning.
I planned to leave these out for the day so Theo could further explore them and use them again. Who knows, maybe he’ll create another game out of it!
What you will need:
Playdough recipe of your choice
Extra: glitter, kool aid or anything else you want to add.
How I approached this:

Theo gets really involved when we make play dough, it tends to be more “fun” for him than playing with it! He mixes with his hands, squishing the dry ingredients and mixing the wet with dry ingredients.

He used to really dislike being dirty and would appear upset if he got anything on himself and about a month ago started becoming “ok” with it. These kinds of sensory activities are most to thank for the change.

For children who dislike having most things other than clothes on them REALLY benefit from getting their hands “dirty.” These kinds of activities will help them become more comfortable with “different” feelings and textures as they did for Theo.
Sensory is so important for young children-they learn through touch and begin to accept other ways of learning.
What you will need:
Easel or chalkboard
Chalk
How I approached this:
Open-ended art for the win! Easy parent prep and great for the little one. Theo already colors a lot, why not switch up his tools to inspire more exploration?

You may notice they may favor one art “tool” over the other- one may be more comfortable for them, however it's great for them to become exposed to new tools and great for their little muscles to use them all.
Using chalk versus paint brushes, crayons, markers, etc. may make them feel “better”, may make them uncomfortable, or at times even both.
Allowing them to explore while they simply just “feel” about it is wonderful for their emotional learning.
What you will need:
Your Bodies
Soft music or guide program
How I approached this:
Today we decided to try some yoga and stretching. This time around with our yoga and stretching I decided to look up some silly poses to correspond with Theo’s interests.
We looked up a few tree poses, dinosaur poses and after a few minutes we began creating our own together (which was so much more beneficial!!) Theo was posing and making animal noises.
He was using his imagination and how he felt to manipulate his body to express himself. As much as I tried planning for this one, I’m glad his emotions and feelings took over
What you will need:
Bubble Wrap (ours was leftover from packages)
How I approached this:
Time to get silly! Now, I have truly learned to keep everything because you can get creative and use things in some way shape or form if you’ve got a little one.
Bubble wrap can be expensive, so I'm sure to keep all or any I get! This may be a good activity to plan ahead for or maybe save for later in the month.

Some children might not like the loud noise with this one. If you think it could upset your little, start with the smaller bubble bubble wraps. Theo jumped right on our medium size bubble wrap and jumped the first few pops as he was getting used to the noise.
But, initially he hopped right on and went crazy! What a cool noise and feeling on their feet!
Sometimes we forget feet are just as good to learn about sensory play! Children get the same (or even better) beneficial sensations through their feet.
I highly recommend switching it up because they may achieve their needs more efficiently that way!
What you will need:
Jell-o (will make it easier if prepared beforehand if you little one is younger, but if they are older you may consider making it with them--learning processes is great!)
How I approached this:
Afraid store bought playdough could hurt your little one and don't have time to make homemade playdough? This is a great, non-toxic alternative. Theo seemed a little confused at first.

He usually asks me, “mouth?” before he puts things in his mouth (thank goodness). It took him a few minutes to ask (after it was already squished between his fingers). When he asked I said it was ok, although he wasn't crazy about the taste/texture.
This is a great activity that won’t cause “worry” of them putting some in their mouths if you need to turn around for a second (because let's face it, we all need a second sometimes.)
Just like playdough you could add toys/manipulatives to it too! It’s differently textured and totally safe. Perfect for your little one who is in the need of a new kind of sensory activity!
What you will need:
Velcro fruits and veggies
How I approached this:
I was out shopping one evening at TJ Max and saw velcro fruit and veggie sets, for a very affordable price (about $5 each set). So I took a gamble and got them both and I'm so glad I did!

He will often use the play knife to cut everything up. We have a spare room in our house, so I have had these out to use at his “convenience.” He takes them out all the time. He has even started to take his snacks in that room and cut them like he cuts the plastic food.
This would be a great activity to take out while you cook (as if they were assisting you) to help keep them busy but also learning. Your child can “help” and have their very own (safe) tools to use.
It can really challenge them to use their small hand muscles, as the play knife is small and thin. What a great way to strengthen them!

title.en-US: Head Shoulders Knees and Toes Song

content.value: What you will need:
Your voice
You
Your little one
How I approached this:

Theo, like many things, takes a lot of involvement with music and movement. “Head, shoulders, knees and toes” has been one of our favorites from the very beginning. He has been very interested in his body and what parts are and where they are on him so I figured this sequencing dance/song would be perfect for him.

We generally always have some sort of music playing, so this time in particular I made sure a few different versions of this one came on a few times. I did this one with him because he still is not sure where everything is. We did it with and without the music and at times would “read” through the song with our book (sometimes the song pace is a little too fast).

It took him a while to find his shoulders, but as we did this more and more he was able to locate them! It can be difficult for young children to locate parts of their body they can't yet see, sometimes it's as if they don't even exist yet until they can see or reach them!

Any sequencing song can help to build cognitive skills. One other favorite of Theo’s is “Baby bumble bee.” Take notice of songs they like and incorporate those! Some children often like new songs so even introducing a new one might grab their attention.
What you will need:
Yourself
A child
Safe tools for children to use to help (paper towels, child sized broom, etc)
How I approached this:

This can be learning on so many levels-probably all developmental standards to be honest. The feeling of helping and completing, having a “responsibility”, and “wantedness” is huge for young children.

They often want to help, be involved and to have some importance. Children thrive off of this. I never see Theo listen and respond so well when I involve him in house tasks. We regularly do them together; unload and load the dishwasher, vacuum, sweep, dust and cook (when appropriate).

He has child sized cleaning tools and we keep them with our adult ones. I am sure to leave them accessible so he doesn't have to wait for me to get involved with the house and our regular responsibilities.

Children love having a purpose and responsibility. Making this possible around the home is easier than you think. Make tools accessible (if appropriate), let them get involved in safe tasks and request their help when you can. They love being needed!
What you will need:
Family Photos or Photo Album
How I approached this:
Theo is constantly looking at photos of family and even himself now or as a baby. Our home is full of framed photos and I'm always taking photos so this kid is surrounded!!

I like to show Theo pictures of him when he was a baby, which really through him off at first because he was just learning about mirrors and what he currently looks like. He used to label himself “baby.”

As he looks at photos of his grandma, papa, uncles and aunties, he’s full of smiles as if he almost feels those silly moments and happy moments all over again! He will often smile as he looks at and talk about the photos we have around the house. What an emotional, wheel turning ride.
What you will need:
Finger Paint (washable is best)
Painting platform of your choice
How I approached this:
What a way to connect with art and relax! I know, most of you are probably thinking, “No way, not in my house!” However, like I have mentioned in the past, there are ways around the “messy!”

Is the weather nice? Do it outside! Just plain nervous about how messy it could get? Pop your kiddo right in the bathtub-if your paint is washable, it will come off everything and it will make for an extra easy clean up of your kiddo.
I absolutely love messy play. I love the way Theo reacts to it, how it makes him feel and the benefits he receives from it.
It stimulates his senses, helps with his intellectual development, is soothing and allows him to use his imagination!
GET MESSY & HAVE FUN!
What you will need:
Storage or tupperware containers that have lids that go on and come off
How I approached this:
I like this “project” because most people own some sort of tupperware or plastic storage. This is a great way to put those little brains to work!

I usually put out 3 or so tupperware pieces and cups that have fitting lids (various sizes) and naturally Theo tries to “close” them all. I stick with three max so it's not initially too challenging, but if you do need to make this a little more difficult, even over time, you can add more to the current you already have out.

If the child is young and hasn't explored like this before, offering more than three can become too overwhelming and can prevent the child from actually wanting to give the activity a go because it appears too difficult.
Then they begin to use them for other purposes (throwing) and just become purley uninterested.
Mix it up! Switch out containers- some big, some small, keep those kiddos working on strengthening those little brains!
What you will need:
Bathroom pipes (bought or homemade)
Bathtub
Water
How I approached this:
We decided to invest in some bath time “tubes” that stick to the bathtub walls (good ol’ amazon). Theo spends a lot of his time playing with any water he can get ahold of.
Bathtime is one of his favorite parts of the day. So it was easy to invest. They are easy to move around and best of all they can be any age appropriate.

How Theo uses them now will not be how he uses them next year. He will figure out he can manipulate them to release water differently and will eventually be able to remove and stick them himself to anywhere around the shower/bath area!
All of the work and thinking it takes for him to fill a cup full of water (which can get heavy) and pour into the tubing is wonderful and the opportunity anf room for experimenting is huge.

All of the tubes are different colors, shapes and release the water differently (and can be manipulated to change how they release water). All of the thoughts and sequencing he is processing during this time is crazy.
No “leading” is needed, children naturally explore new objects and get more out of things when they are “in charge.” These really trigger those little wheels to start turning when they are out!
What you will need:
Paint
Paper
Think Paint Brushes
How I approached this:
As much as we love free painting art or art with larger stems to hold, I was really focused on Theo and noticed he was choosing thinner stemmed brushes than usual.

Those little muscles of his are feeling a new type of grip and aren't minding them. It's really important to offer a variety. Then they are able to learn to be comfortable with many different varieties of items, whether it be paint brushes or other toys and manipulatives.

The more practice they have with different types of items, the more they strengthen those little muscles that need a little workout here and there. If you want to spruce it up a bit, add large and small toys and objects to a painting activity (driving big and small cars through the paint to make art, etc.)
Any practice is good practice!
What you will need:
Park Location
Your Kiddo
How I approached this:
So we improvised today. As nice as the park would have been, (IF other children had been there when we would have) we decided to play in our backyard instead.

There was so much opportunity for play and learning right outside our door. Although it was so slippery out we made the best of it! Theo rode his “bike”, pushed his truck, his cart and chased the dogs around.

He also got some awesome sensory play in (thanks to our cold/ice melting weather) ☺️ Theo was cracking ice and playing with the pieces of ice and the water underneath. He was “fishing out” his car keys in the shallow ice water.
Although we weren't able to try and play with others today (weather related), Theo was able to get in so much learning and exploration.

Sometimes plans don't work out but we figure more out so our littles can enjoy and flourish in their learning journey. YES we did not get to socialize at the park, however we got gross motor, sensory and exploration in our own backyard and were safe while doing so.
Mother nature set up our learning space, how much better does it get than that?
What you will need:
Puzzles!
How I approached this:
Theo has one puzzle in particular that he does a lot and knows well and he has two that challenge him but he is willing to try more than once. To keep his interest I frequently switch out puzzles.

This way his brain is always being challenged. Now I'm not saying a 50 piece puzzle BUT I am saying challenge to an extent that's good for him (all children will be different). I never have them all out at the same time, this could be too overwhelming for him because he is so young.

It’s good for young children to see things more than once-this gives them time to process and learn through repetition. As “simple” as puzzles may seem for an activity, it will sure give their little noggins a workout!
What you will need:
A balance Beam (piece of wood, metal, plastic anything really)
How I approached this:

For this activity I used an old (somewhat long) piece of wood we had from a previous project. It worked so well and we didn't spend a dime! Theo spent time trying his best to walk it and then got creative and began to jump over it!

Since he is in gymnastics he has walked a beam before which could have made it easy for him to see it as a beam, but if your child has not done anything like this, you may have to show them different ways of using it at first! If a thicker slab is too easy for your kiddo, go ahead and offer a thinner one.
Still too easy? Use a few pieces of wood to make the beam change directions, almost like a maze! Balance and coordination will get lots of practice here!!
